awd_titl_txt: Physics and Phenomenology of Galactic Winds
awd_abstract_narration:
The stars, like our Sun, generate winds of very hot particles that fill the space between stars.  Particle winds are also created in clouds of gas where stars form, and especially strong winds occur during supernovae explosions.   The investigators will study the physics, evolution, dynamics, and implications of the different sources of galactic winds in several types of galaxies, from star-forming dwarf galaxies to ultra-luminous starburst galaxies.

A significant part of the proposed work will be carried out by graduate students, providing training in cutting-edge research. Results will be broadly disseminated by publication in peer-reviewed journals, conference proceedings, and by the press. In addition, the investigators propose an education and outreach component that targets senior citizens,  an important and growing, yet traditionally significantly under-served group.

The investigators will provide deliverables that will broadly impact the scientific community. They will directly evaluate the importance of new physics for the structure of galactic winds, an important guide to the essential physics for current and future multi-dimensional simulations. They will isolate important physical effects in time-dependent simulations that may provide the key pieces to allow modelers to understand their calculations. Finally, they will provide a tool for connecting the underlying theory to observations and vice versa. Overall, this proposal serves to community in two ways --- first, by exploring newly opened up discovery spaces and second, by mapping these spaces for those who can use the results immediately. 

The investigators' goal is to simultaneously address the physics and phenomenology of galactic winds, connecting theory and observation. They will do both broad sweeps through parameter space, and focused studies of individual systems. Among the projects they will pursue, they will (1) calculate the ram pressure acceleration of cool clouds by hot outflows, (2) understand the ability of hot metal-rich winds to cool radiatively, producing cool clouds in situ, (3) assess the interaction of a hot flow, potentially loaded with cool clouds, with the surrounding circumgalactic medium in an effort to explain recent observations, (4) calculate the acceleration of clouds by momentum deposition, including a comparison of theory and data for individual galaxies and large surveys, (5) understand the interaction of momentum deposition in turbulence, and (6) calculate the dynamics of two-fluid dust+gas radiation hydrodynamical flows.

por.por_cntn:
Galactic winds are a critical component to the evolution and growth of galaxies. They eject the raw fuel for star formation, and thus prevent, prolong, and sometimes terminate the formation of stars in galaxies. As such, they help dictate the total number of stars in the universe and the stellar content of galaxtic systems.

Galactic winds also eject metals and dust into the circumgalactic and intergalactic medium, affecting the abundances of these critical components in stellar systems in galaxies. In this way, galactic winds are directly connected to the formation of planets and planetary systems, and to the abundance of elements like Carbon, Nitrogen, Oxygen, Silicon, Magnesium, and Iron in the gaseous medium of galaxies. Galactic winds are thus connected to the origin of life as we know it.

Critically, the driving mechanism of galactic winds is unknown.  Although many processes have been proposed -- like supernova explosions, radiation pressure, and cosmic ray pressure -- there is no clear physics that has been shown to dominate wind driving over a range of galaxy parameters, and that explains observations within that range. 

The purpose of this grant has been to develop theories of galactic winds and gas ejection from galaxies and to compare aspects of the theories with the wealth of observations that now exist in different wavebands, probing different gas tracers and dynamical components from galaxies at all times in the evolution of the universe. 

This grant has partially funded the PhD thesis work of four Ohio State graduate students. Approximately 30 papers have been submitted or published. Key science results from the grant include a critical assessment of cold cloud entrainment in galactic winds, a calculation of the long-term interaction of galactic winds with their surrounding circumgalactic medium, simulations of radiation pressure-driven turbulence, an explanation for the cool gas in galactic winds as radiative cooling in mass-loaded hot winds, a new calculation of the maximum flux of star-forming galaxies and the efficiency of star cluster formation based on radiation pressure and an analogous analysis for cosmic rays, a first detection of the ultra-luminous galaxy Arp 220 in gamma-rays, and evidence for cosmic ray escape in the wind from the Small Magellanic Cloud. Recent works include our study of mass-loading and X-ray surface brightness profiles in hot galactic winds, and new theoretical models for cosmic ray driven outflows .

Broader Impacts from this grant include about 30 individual public lectures for a popular audience in the last 4 years, including a lecture for over 800 people at Fermilab National Accelerator, and more than a dozen professional seminars for graduate students, postdocs, and staff at Ohio State University on how to give better scientific talks, and how to apply for postdoctoral and faculty positions.
